data.title: The Complete Disney Canon Actors Table
data.meta_description: Experience the legacy of the Disney canon in a whole new way!
data.text:
Hello everyone, and welcome to a new post! For the first time in months, I’ve actually found time to put something together that is not a book review (not that there’s anything wrong with those, it’s just good to have some variety). This little project is something I’ve been meaning to do for quite some time now, so I’m happy to finally present it to you – a complete table of every voice actor ever to appear in the Disney canon films, from Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs way back in 1937, all the way up to Wish. Not all of the people on the list have publicly known birthdates, but I’ve still included everybody who ever played a named part, however small (excluding those who provided “additional voices”), in tribute to their work.

This is more for reference than anything else. I’m a massive nerd, it’s true, but I just find it fascinating to see all these names together, more than a thousand people born across a span of roughly 150 years, all representing a small part of the same animated legacy. At the very top of the list is Otis Harlan, the voice of Happy in Snow White, who was born in the same year as the Lincoln assassination and the end of the Civil War in the mid-1860s. Interestingly, he was born the day before Rudyard Kipling, whose work would go on to inspire one of Disney’s most popular films! He is part of an unbroken line stretching all the way out to 2015, when the youngest member of the list, Paisley Herrera, was born (she played one of the kids bothering Mirabel at the start of Encanto). I wonder if she’s heard of him?

Another interesting fact worth mentioning is that as of this writing (October 2022), we have twelve actors from the 1920s still with us:

Cate Bauer (one of two voices for Perdita in One Hundred and One Dalmatians)

Carole Cook (Pearl Gesner in Home on the Range) {NOTE: Ms. Cook passed away on the 11th of January, 2023}

Eve Brenner (the Mouse Queen in Great Mouse Detective)

Angela Lansbury (Mrs. Potts in Beauty and the Beast) {NOTE: Sadly, Ms. Lansbury passed away on the 11th of October, 2022, just a few days after posting this}

David Frankham (Sergeant Tibbs in One Hundred and One Dalmatians)

William Glover (Winston from Oliver & Company)

Fred Darian (the Minstrel from the opening of The Sword in the Stone)

James Hong (Chi-Fu in Mulan)

Margaret Kerry (the mermaids in Peter Pan)

Bob Newhart (Bernard in The Rescuers and The Rescuers Down Under) {NOTE: Mr. Newhart passed away on the 18th of July, 2024}

Joan Plowright (Baylene in Dinosaur)

June Squibb (Jimmy’s grandma in Ralph Breaks the Internet)

The oldest living Disney voice actor may be Cate Bauer, but there’s some confusion on that point. You see, Ms. Bauer has two different birthdates floating around the web; one puts her at 94, born in 1929, but the other puts her at 101, born in 1922. Whichever is correct, she and the other people on this list are living treasures for Disney fans, and we should be deeply grateful that they are still with us at their ages.

{NOTE: It is actually between Cate Bauer, Eve Brenner, David Frankham and William Glover! Bauer, Brenner and Glover all have ambiguous birthdates, so Frankham is the oldest with a definite age}.

On a sadder note, the youngest actor on the list to have left us is Jason Raize, the voice of Denahi in Brother Bear. Born in 1975, he was going through some personal struggles around the time of the film’s release, and tragically committed suicide a few months after the premiere, aged just 28. Mary Kay Bergman had a similarly tragic end a few years earlier, at the age of 38. The list is full of stories, complicated lives and personalities, an eclectic collection of people whose one shared characteristic is their contribution to the Disney legacy.

{NOTE: Sadly, this is no longer true. As of February 2023, the youngest actor on the list to have passed away is now Austin Majors, the voice of young Jim in Treasure Planet, born in 1995}.

One final bit of trivia before I let you delve into the list for yourself; you may be curious to know the ages of the Disney princesses, perhaps Disney’s best-known single group of characters after the classics like Mickey, Donald and Goofy. Here they are, with their age at date of death or the age they will reach this year.

Adriana Caselotti: 1916 – 1997 (80)

Ilene Woods: 1929 – 2010 (81)

Mary Costa: 1930 (94)

Paige O’Hara: 1956 (68)

Judy Kuhn: 1958 (66)

Jodi Benson: 1961 (63)

Ming-Na Wen: 1963 (61)

Irene Bedard: 1967 (57)

Linda Larkin: 1970 (54)

Lea Salonga: 1971 (53)

Idina Menzel: 1971 (53)

Anika Noni Rose: 1972 (52)

Kelly Macdonald: 1976 (48)

Kristen Bell: 1980 (44)

Mandy Moore: 1984 (40)

Kelly Marie Tran: 1989 (35)

Auli’i Cravalho: 2000 (24)

So, there you have it. I hope you find this useful, or at least interesting to look through; it was certainly a labour of love to put together! Enjoy, and until next time, staaay animated!

{UPDATED 19/07/24}
